title: Starting to see first hand that new GA is bad for the game
body: Snowballing is a part of this game. It happens. But when we reward champions who snowball an item that also adds to their overall damage output, lets them tank a little bit more, and gain a free life, that's when we start seeing how this game gets out of hand. It isn't uncommon to see champions like {{champion:121}} or {{champion:92}} to take out 2 or 3 champions instantly. So after they "die" after acquiring that double, they are still big enough to revive and just lather rinse repeat unless they somehow got caught out. It was fine when this item didn't add to their damage output, but now they have an optimal item that provides damage, defense, and potentially a free pass.

The first misstep is even thinking about adding AD onto a completely defensive item whose existence is to snowball an already winning team harder, or to try and create an edge to snowball on in later stages of the game. It has also never been a core build thanks to its completely defensive stats hence it's not everyone's favourite to immediate rush onto (which thank god), but now it is, and it's creating a massive problem.

Hell, the current item name also makes no sense to its own stats now too. Why would a "Guardian Angel" give their subject more AD? At least if you have to, make its offence qualities something along the lines of Sunfire Cape or Dead Man's Plate or something, straight up giving the character more AD is just imo unfathomably stupid on so many levels.

Let's be real, I rather suspect the very reason why this change was passed, was trying to fix the imaginary "lol adc 2k17" issue that's never there in the first place. And even if you have to "fix" it, why would the most ridiculous solution be the one that ultimately passes the QA? I don't get it.

Sure, do more testing, I insist. But in the end, I highly wish the change would simply be reverted instead of having more random changes that drives the rabbit hole further, or even end up straight-up ruining this iconic item such as having the revival removed, all because of this 1 utterly silly mistake that shouldn't have happened to begin with.

Because Riot has been catering to the "no damage is unfun" idea for quite a long while. Players "felt bad" that they had to buy items designed to make them tankier and "lose out" on buying damage instead. So now Riot has taken it upon themselves to remove the bad, icky feeling by putting defense on offensive items and offense on defensive items.

It's one of many missteps that Riot is unlikely to admit or go back on.

It also allows people to play damage-dealers without requiring a perfectly put together frontline backline strat, because playing pure damage characters in any game is a great way to die the instant any enemy with any sort of threat can reach you.

If not for life-extending tools on marksmen and the like, they'd either have to do so much more damage or be tossed in the gutter. Allowing DPSers more time to live means they are allowed to get their job done later rather than soon - which means rocket tag gameplay can be avoided and we don't a game that would be akin to League composed entirely of full-build assassins in their strongest state.

Or, and maybe I'm crazy, but carry/assassin players could expect to build at least one defensive item in every game where they aren't fed and actually rely on their teammates for the bulk of their protection. It's a team game, afterall. Expected time in combat can be done on a base-stat level, like game-wide changes to HP or damage output (be that up or down, depending).

It's far too late to head down that path, though. Riot seems intent on preventing players from buying "feel-bad items."

To be perfectly blunt, if you think an item where you sink half the cost into defensive stats and tools doesn't count as a "defensive item" in a game where the best offensive items get you gold efficiency of 95% to 105% from raw offensive value, then your itemization is kinda trash for DPS.

I mean, another hybrid offense-defense item in Maw only gets 62% efficiency from offensive stats, and while that's booted up to 83.6% while its passive is active ... that is actually a _lot_ of value missing from the passive, because most of it is dedicated to defensive effects. Not to mention that offensive value from the passive is worsened by the fact that you need to take magic damage and be taken below 30% health to trigger it, meaning that it has to be carried with other defensive stats to leverage it well or else you'll just get blown up by physical damage before you can benefit from it.

Also, to put it in perspective, Bloodthirster is 78.9% efficient from raw damage, but it also has a huge chunk of life steal that is always active, which means that its main defensive component scales _really_ well with DPS, unlike GA's armor and revival which don't interact with DPS at all, or Maw while inactive and doing it far worse while inactive. It also effectively provides 120 - 350 bonus health depending on how soon you get it, which is only a bit under the health Sterak's gives late in the game, which makes it a completely efficient item ... at level 2, when that effective health is 60.

Blade of the Ruined King is another example. Its minimum offensive efficiency is only 71.8% in comparison to Bloodthrister ... if it's attacking a target with less than 188 health. Against a target with 1000 or more health? 118.4% of offensive stats and rising at the health rises, before factoring in defensive stats. Which, since it gives only 5% less life steal than Bloodthrister, also scales really well the user's DPS, which BotR provides a lot of bang for its price tag against anyone who isn't limping or severely underleveled. And that's _before_ factoring in its active, which is a great tool for offensive chasing or defensive kiting ...

I mean, BotRK is even _really good right now_.

It's really just you guys having arbitrary definitions of what's "right" for a DPS's defensive item. As long as it's life steal or otherwise has no offensive value whatsoever, it's fine. As soon as armor or magic resist find itself on an item with 20 AD, though? Comment chains like this happen. It's pretty inane, especially from the perspective of someone who plays both League and DOTA.

Not going to win any arguments here with the "I play League and Dota" line, particularly with me.

Mercurial Scimitar only exists because Riot thought it was "bad" for a ranged carry to need the QSS active but gain no damage out of the deal. That design philosophy has permeated every "defensive" item by tacking on needless damage just to make the item less of a "bad choice" in the situation where you'd actually care to get an item with defensive stats. Sometimes it's done so badly that other roles cannibalize the item from the intended role (an argument I won't get into, because I don't think this is a problem on its face).

You want to argue stat efficiency, and I'm arguing that these items shouldn't have damage stats to begin with when you're picking them up for their defensive qualities. Lifesteal is really the only acceptable exception since the defensive quality of lifesteal is entirely dependent on damage to function at all.
